Award.AwardTitle: Improving Access and Success in Information Technology Programs Through Education-Industry Connections
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to improve the quality of the information technology (IT) workforce by improving access, equity, and success in community college IT programs of study. It focuses on the needs of students from groups that are currently underrepresented in the IT sector. Effective education models have been developed to close the gender and minority achievement gap in STEM fields. However, most of these models have focused on STEM degree completion at four-year institutions. This project will adapt these baccalaureate pipeline models to a two-year IT technician education program. Project activities will include improving gateway courses through strong industry connections and experiential learning. The improvements will be designed to lessen culturally grounded barriers and self-limiting behaviors. The project expects to develop an effective and replicable model for improving the success of students, particularly underrepresented students, and thus contribute to the quality and diversity of the nation's IT workforce.

This project includes a partnership between the University of Florida Institute of Higher Education and Indian River Community College. The overall goal is to increase the enrollment and persistence of students, especially women and underrepresented minority students, in IT programs of study. Specific aims include reconceptualizing three high-stakes gateway courses, embedding industry certifications in program coursework, providing students with internships and mentoring, and increasing the successful transfer of students from the community college into IT bachelors degree programs. The project includes a mixed-methods research protocol to investigate perceived obstacles, self-limiting behaviors, and the effectiveness of project interventions. Through a focus on access, graduation, and post-graduation success, the project intends to improve diversity throughout the IT industry pipeline. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The iConnect project was an innovative intervention focused on improving access and success in information technology (IT) programs at Indian River State College (IRSC). To do so, the project incorporated a series of data-driven approaches to increase enrollment and academic outcomes among female and racially minoritized students in IRSC IT programs. The project began in April 2020 and continued through March 2024. During this four-year period, researchers from the University of Florida’s Institute of Higher Education (UF-IHE) and IRSC worked collaboratively to reconceptualize and redesign five entry-level IT courses, improve alignment between IT programs and industry expectations, and enhance interest in IT through a summer bridge outreach program.

Our collaborative team of instructional designers and faculty completed course audits and identified critical needs to increase student interaction and engagement while better aligning course content with IT workforce skills and expectations. Working with IRSC IT faculty and industry representatives, we reconceptualized instructional content for the following five core IT courses: 1) CIS 1000 - Introduction to Information Technology, 2) COP 2000 - Introduction to Computer Programming, 3) COP 2030 - Introduction to Python, 4) CET 1178 - A+ Certification Hardware, and 5) CET 1179 - A+ Certification Software. In addition to revamping IT instructional content, our project team launched virtual coding labs and strengthened industry connections through embedded industry certifications, internships, and mentoring opportunities.

To enhance awareness and interest in IT careers among underrepresented students, we expanded pre-collegiate outreach through a targeted summer bridge program and strengthened both workforce-focused recruitment and advising. This approach is designed to better inform and support underrepresented students who were considering IT credentials and career pathways.

We examined the experiences and outcomes associated with the iConnect project through a mixed methods evaluation approach. We completed two rounds of interviews focused on female and racially minoritized IT students’ perceptions and experiences. In total, we interviewed 86 IRSC IT students. The qualitative findings revealed that female and racially underrepresented students highlighted a variety of barriers faced while enrolled in IT coursework, including considerable challenges with online education, inefficient course-taking patterns, and limited built-in experiences designed to prepare students for the IT workforce. These qualitative findings helped to inform multiple aspects of the project intervention design.

Our quantitative findings indicated a positive relationship between the iConnect intervention and enrollment in IT programs, particularly among female and racially minoritized students. Between Spring 2020 and Fall 2023, a total of 2,257 IRSC students enrolled in one of the five core IT courses, including 538 women and 1,112 racially minoritized students. Prior to the iConnect intervention, 42.7% of underrepresented students who took one of the IT courses actually enrolled in IRSC IT programs. Following the iConnect intervention, 64.9% of underrepresented students who took one of the IT courses enrolled in IRSC IT programs. Our regression analysis revealed a positive and statistically significant relationship between the iConnect intervention and IRSC IT program enrollment (27.4 percentage points). Although the project was positively related to access in IT at IRSC, success outcomes, such as IT course performance, IT persistence, and baccalaureate matriculation in IT, were not statistically significant.

Taken together, iConnect project components were associated with increases in the number and proportion of underrepresented students who enrolled in IRSC IT programs. This project was focused specifically on IT access and success among underrepresented students at one high-enrollment community college, but it provides important groundwork for future practice and research designed to increase IT participation among underrepresented community college students. The intellectual merit of these interventions lies in their potential to improve access for underrepresented students in technology-focused STEM degree programs. Women and racially minoritized students continue to be underrepresented in STEM majors, particularly in IT disciplines. The broader impact of iConnect is rooted in its potential to enhance underrepresented students’ opportunities to pursue IT credentials and enter the IT workforce. Project findings represent an important step toward addressing the statewide and national shortage of qualified IT professionals. 


Last Modified: 05/24/2024
Modified by: Justin C Ortagus
